title: Ticket #1601: git update hook to not accept commits from user unknown
description:
Be nice to have git update hook to reject commits from user "unknown", aka from a user that never initialized their git setup correctly/completely.

An example of a commit we'd like to have been auto-rejected is [18860].
remarks:
2010-Aug-24 12:54:50 by jfrey:
I've added a check in the update hook the rejects pushes where the last commit's author or commiter name is 'unknown'.

This only helps for Windows users who haven't configured their git identity. On unix, git falls back on using the machine name and the user's full name and username from the passwd file. Maybe we need a more restrictive check, like the git id must match one of the following patterns: 

  *@cs.wisc.edu
  *@wisc.edu
  *@cyclecomputing.com
  *@redhat.com
  *@marquette.edu
  jaeyoungyoon@gmail.com
  rosso@gravity.phys.uwm.edu
  sateesh.potturu@wipro.com

Keeping the list up-to-date for new outside collaborators could get annoying.

2010-Aug-24 13:50:34 by tannenba:
I think what you did is good enough for now. I don't think we need to make this an authorization check, we are getting that via AFS permissions.

Gonna resolve this ticket.
creator: tannenba
